name: Monstera Deliciosa
toxicityText: The foliage results in irritations for cats, dogs and humans. The fruits are edible to humans (and very tasty!).
description: Native to Central America, Monsteras became famous for their unique aesthetic and their natural leaf-holes. This eventually led to the nickname, Swiss Cheese Plant.

name: Rattlesnake Plant
toxicityText: This plant is non toxic for animals and humans.
description: Native to the Brazilian rainforest, this plant thrives in moist, warm, semi-shady climates and can grow bright yellow-orange blooms in late spring and early summer.

name: ZZ Plant
toxicityText: ZZ plants are poisonous to both humans and pets. Side-effects are stomach ache, vomiting and diarrhoea if ingested.
description: The ZZ Plant is native to Eastern Africa. Having evolved in drier conditions, this plant is very forgiving when it comes to watering.

name: Snake Plant
toxicityText: Ingestion is not advised. Large doses can cause nausea and vomiting. The poison found in the plant has a numbing effect that can cause the tongue and throat to swell. The plants are more toxic to dogs and cats, which can suffer from nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea.
description: These plants are one of the toughest you can find. In stronger natural light they’ll grow faster and slower in lower light.

name: Peace Lily
toxicityText: The leaves of the Peace Lily can be poisonous if eaten in large quantities to animals and humans. Symptoms include severe pain in the mouth and a burning sensation to the lips, tongue, and throat, excessive drooling, vomiting and difficulty swallowing.
description: An adaptable and low-maintenance houseplant. Even though the flowers of this plant resemble those of lilies, they don’t belong to the same family.

name: Dracaena
toxicityText: This plant is poisonous for animals. Symptoms may include vomiting, diarrhoea, abdominal pain and dilated pupils for cats.
description: The plant care routine for Dracaena is fairly simple. They can withstand a certain amount of neglect and come with great air purification capabilities.

name: Prayer Plant
toxicityText: This plant is non toxic for animals and humans.
description: Although prayer plant houseplant is somewhat tolerant of low light conditions, it does best in bright, indirect sunlight.

name: Dumb Cane
toxicityText: Ingestion of this plant is poisonous to humans and pets. The sap of the plant is acrid, and, when ingested, will numb the throat and vocal cords, rendering the victim mute for up to two weeks until the poison wears off. The sap is also highly irritating to the skin and the eyes.
description: Large, lush, variegated leaves make dumb cane an attractive houseplant. Dieffenbachia will adapt to different environments and require little attention from you.

name: Spider Plant
toxicityText: This plant is non toxic for animals and humans.
description: Usually grown in hanging baskets, this South African native plant is quick to adapt to any environment and usually cause little problems.

name: Rojo Congo
toxicityText: Rojo Congos contain a toxin in their leaves called calcium oxalate. Ingestion by pets or humans could cause inflammation of the mucus membranes in the mouth and throat.
description: This plant gets the name ‘rojo’ from its new leaves, which unfurl in a deep, shiny red. However, as the leaves mature, it will fade to a burgundy green colour.

name: Fiddle-Leaf Fig
toxicityText: Ingestion of this plant can be poisonous for pets. Symptoms range from oral irritation or swelling to vomiting.
description: The fiddle leaf fig is native to western Africa and grows naturally in a lowland rainforest environment.

name: Rubber Plant
toxicityText: The Rubber Plant is mildly poisonous to pets and humans. The plants have a milky irritating sap in the stems and leaves that can cause gastrointestinal issues if eaten and skin irritation if the sap is allowed to rest on the skin for a time or gets into small cuts.
description: Native to southern Asia, this easy to care plant can grow up to 200 feet tall in its natural habitat. Keep the soil moist in summer to speed up the growth.

name: Money Tree
toxicityText: Generally speaking, this plant is non toxic for pets and humans. While some advise that the leaves may have some poisonous characteristics, the symptoms are very mild and remain mostly unnoticed.
description: Easily distinguished by its braided trunk, the Money Tree is perfect for indoor foliage. It is also widely considered as a symbol of luck and prosperity.

name: Aloe Vera
toxicityText: Aloe Veras are usually known for their health benefits. Though, the sap of the leaves should not be ingested. Symptoms range from abdominal cramping to diarrhoea. The gel is mostly safe and only causes skin irritation in conjunction to allergies.
description: One of the most popular succulent plant of the world. It also comes with great beneficial properties. The plant strives in bright, direct sunlight.

name: Golden Pothos
toxicityText: Every part of this plant is poisonous to animals and humans. Ingestion may cause oral/ skin irritation, pain and swelling of mouth, tongue, and lips, vomiting and diarrhoea. Please avoid having this plant if you have pets or children.
description: Arguably one of the easiest houseplants to grow. This trailing vine thrives in direct sun but can also stay in areas that don’t get a lot of sunlight.

name: Monkey Leaf
toxicityText: Monkey Leaf Monsteras are toxic to both people and animals - keep away from small children and pets.
description: Commonly refered as the little brother of the Monstera Deliciosa, this vining Monstera is perfect for every household.

name: Schefflera
toxicityText: While Scheffleras are only mildly toxic to humans, ingestion of the plant can still lead to vomiting and numbness. Pets that ingest the plant can experience vomiting, oral irritation and excessive drooling.
description: Often called 'umbrella plant' due to the long, oval leaves that droop gracefully from a central stalk. The amount of leaflets vary from 6 to 12 depending on the age of the plant.
